On This Day In 1978, Kapil Dev Made His Test Debut And Would Go On To Become One Of The Best In The Format

On This Day In 1978, Kapil Dev Made His Test Debut And Would Go On To Become One Of The Best In The Format

We fondly remember the sight of Kapil Dev holding the World Cup trophy aloft on the Lord's balcony in 1983, but one of India's most revered captains had many other remarkable highlights in his career.

Getty Images

Today, also marks 41 years since the great Kapil Dev made his Test debut against Pakistan. The then 19 year-old took the field in Faisalabad after being touted as the the next big thing in Indian cricket.

He didn't make the most auspicious start - 1 for 96 and eight runs in the match. It might have not have been the dream start, but there was evidence to suggest Kapil Dev was set for a very successful career.

Getty Images

Don't Miss 2.5 K SHARES

The Chandigarh born native was not express pace, but he was one who also got the ball in right channels and swinging. In a Test career that spanned 16 years, Kapil Dev would go on to become one of the greatest allrounders to grace the game of cricket.

His greatest feats were to lead India almost jauntily, and by his all-round example, to the 1983 World Cup, and to take the world-record aggregate of Test wickets from Richard Hadlee. It was the stamina of the marathon runner that took him finally to 434 wickets.

In times when Indian cricket struggled to maintain a foothold in the game, and were an average side, Kapil Dev was always the shining light. It was not just his wicket taking ability, but also his contributions with the bat that made him impact and important player that he was.

In 131 Tests, former Indian captain scored more than 5000 runs at an average of shade over 31, which is exceptional considering he was India's leading bowler and among the wickets. consistently.

Getty Images

He might not have been quite the bowling equal of Imran, Hadlee or Botham at his best, and his strike rate was less than four wickets per Test, but he was still outstanding in his accuracy and ability to swing the ball, usually away from right-handers. And he could hit a ball even more brilliantly than he bowled it, with uncomplicated flair.

At his peak, Kapil Dev bowling was the best sight in world cricket. His spirit still lives through the current crop of Indian bowlers.
